Professor's Letter Stirs Growing Controversy
Increasing
controversy
has
emerged
surrounding the publication of a letter from a
faculty member in the Philosophy Department,
informing all graduate students of the
Department that he considered resorts to
violence in an attempt to gain an end one of the
Worst crimes which could be committed in an
academic institution.
The professor implied that if any students in
the department participated in violent or unruly
demonstrations, they should not expect him to
write letters of recommendation for them.
The letter was distributed among the students
Of the Philosophy Department late last month,
and though there were some angry reactions, it
seemed as though no controversy would develop
over the correspondence. Since that time, the
letter has been read publicly and revealed to
many of its author's colleagues.
No Publicity
The professor who wrote the letter strongly
oPPosed any publicity over it and the reaction
to it. His name, not revealed at the public
reading of the letter at the Tuesday teach-in, will
remain unrevealed until next week at the
earliest.
The letter stated that the professor was
profoundly troubled" by recent events on
Other campuses. A disagreement with a student
over a moral issue, stated the letter, would not
affect that student's grades within the
department. However, the letter continued,"My
°Pinion of an indivual's respect for the nature of
an academic community is, I am bound to say,
°Re of the most important of my opinions
regarding him as a teacher."
The professor declined to comment on any
Part of the letter's contents or on any reactions

he had received to it. He resents the fact that a
he
which
considered
letter
private
correspondence has made its way into the news.
Although the letter was sent to every graduate
student in the department, the professor noted
that he had used his personal stationery and
refrained from any mention of the department
or the university.
Stifled Opinion
The letter has drawn angry response from
several graduate students in the department.
However, they are not prepared to affix their
names to any criticism of the professor,
considering the influence which his opinion may
have over their professional careers.
At the teach-in and rally Tuesday, the letter
was read aloud by Dr. John S. Mann, Professor
of Education. Dr. Mann stressed that those
present should draw their own conclusions from.
the text of the letter, in contrast to an SDS
member who presented it as a "Piece of
academic blackmail,"
After reading the letter, Dr. Mann added "as a
member of the Johns Hopkins faculty, I am
profoundly ashamed of this letter." He
continued, saying "I will not reveal who wrote
this letter, but I urge him to come forth and
justify this to his students and to the entire
community."
The graduate students of the Philosophy
Department intend to meet today to discuss the
letter and get clarification on delicate points
from its author. The consensus of the graduate
students who were interviewed by the
News-Letter was that the letter was ambiguous.
The matter was so complex, they contended,
that "a few anonymous quotes won't reveal the
feeling in the Department."

Many of the letter's critics refer to it .as an'
attempt to coerce the students into a certain
position on moral issues. If this is the case, they
contend, the author of the letter has exceeded
his rights and academic prerogatives.
However, many make it clear that this is not
an isolated case. According to Dr. Stephen
Ambrose, Professor of History, there have b9en
many such cases as this in the last five years. In
most of these cases, however, knowledge of the
attempt to sway moral stands or opinions has
never left the confines of the department.

250 Student Leaders Sign Anti-War Statement
(CPS)-More than 250 student body presidents
and campus newspaper editors, including
News-Letter editors Peter Harnik and Richard
Cramer, and ex-editor Bruce Drake, have signed
a statement opposing the Vietnam war and have
said they will refuse induction into* the armed
forces as long as the war continues.
The statement, released by the National Student
Association, has been sent to President Nixon, along
with a request for an appointment "to share more fully"
with him the students' concern over the war and the
draft.
The signers say, "We will act according to our
conscience. Along with thousands of our fellow
students, we campus leaders cannot participate in a war
which we believe to be immoral and unjust...We publicly
and collectively express our intention to refuse
induction and to aid and support those whc decide to
refuse. We will not serve in the military as long as the
war in Viet-Nam continues."
Position Is Widespread.
The statement was circulated to demonstrate how
Widespread this position is among persons who hold
elected offices and positions of responsibility on college
campuses, NSA officials said. The signers come from ivy

league, big ten denominational, teacher and community
colleges.
"Mr. President," the latter signed by nine of the
students said, "We urgently write to you now...to advise
you that many of the basic questions students and other
concerned Americans have raised about our purposes in
Viet-Nam remain unanswered...We must now number
ourselves among those students who cannot at this time
square military duty with integrity and conscience."
The overall statement also said: "Most of us have
worked in electoral politics and through other channels
to change the course of America's foreign policy and to
remove the inequities of the draft system. We will
continue to work in these ways, but the results of these
efforts will come too late for those whose deferments
will soon expire. We must make an agonizing choice: to
accept induction into the armed forces, which we feel
would be irresponsible to ourselves, our country, and
our fellow man;or to refuse induction, which is contrary
to our-respect for law and involves injury to our personal
lives and our careers."
Peaceful Settlement
"Students have, for a long time now, made known
their desire for a peaceful settlement. The present
negotiations, however, are not an end in themselves, but

rather the means to a complete cease-fire and American
extrication. And until that cease-fire has been reached,
young men who oppose the war will continue .to face the
momentous decision of how to ,respond to the!draft,"
the statement said.

Will Refuse Induction
Eight of the nine who signed the letter to Nixon held
a press conference on Capitol Hill to issue personal
.statements. Wayne Hurder, editor of the Daily Tar Heel
at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, said
he can "no longer duck the issue of an immoral draft
and an immoral war." He said he is not going to seek a
Conscientious Objector classification as first planned,
but will refuse induction.
At the press conference, Rep. Allard K. Lowenstein
(D-N.Y.) said the nation should start looking at society's
problems from the perspective of young people if it
wants to understand them both. Sen. Mark 0. Hatfield
(R-Ore.) issued a statement saying, "I think it is
imperative that we seek to understand the terrible
Idilemma which these young men face. The war and draft
are two pressing and relevant issues, that, hopefully, can
.be influenced by student conviction and action. For the
'government to ignore their kinds of efforts is to risk
further alienating large segments of our young people.".

Two Groups Circulate Anti-SDS Petitions
By RICHARD HEDDLESON
In response to the sit-in last Tuesday at
Homewood House, two student groups have
circulated petitions which condemn the use of
violence and "outside agitators" to further
student demands.
The first petitions is being promoted by three
residents of Gildersleeve House, in the freshman dorms.
The petition "deplores the forceful entry and use of
outside agitators by the SDS and the NUC." The
freshmen spearheading this petition are Bill Strisever,
Richard McKenna and Wayne Matus. They decided to
circulate the petition .after \ a group of ten or so got
together and talked about our extreme dislike for the
tactics being used by the SDS," according to McKenna.
"Initiation of Force"
The other petition is being circulated under the
direction of upperclassmen Bill Van Doren, Michael
Marcus and Laurence Shatkin. It states that the
"University should neither recognize nor negotiate with
any group that uses the initiation of force." It also asks
the University to state that it will protect members of
the community from coercive violence and to stop "any
future occupation of university property by whatever
legitimate means are necessary." Further, it calls for the
punishment of acts of violence and coercion and the
expulsion of repeated offenders.
Unlike the freshman petition, the upperclass
petition is not a spontaneous reaction to the Tuesday
sit-in. "We made provisions to take actions like this four
months ago," stated Van Doren. The students had
previously organized an ad hoc Committee Against
Student Terrorism. Van Doren said that the committee

ABM Threat Continues to Haunt Congress
By SENATOR JOSEPH D. TYDINGS
Special to the News-Letter
The Administration's decision to
deploy the Safeguard anti-ballistic
missile system is one of the most crucial
matters to come before Congress in this
decade. For there is more at stake than
an enormously expensive complex of
military equipment. We are being asked
to make a decision that could easily
affect our national security and the
course of the arms race, as well as the
very nature of our society in the years
ahead.
Our defense budget has expanded at
an incredible rate, to the point where
defense-related
military
and
expenditures consume more than
two-thirds of every American income
tax dollar. Congressional failure to
carefully analyze and evaluate defense
spending has permitted much waste and
duplication.
Given our unprecedented inflation,
the growing burden of the American
taxpayer, and the implacable urgency of
our domestic problems, this "buy
whatever the generals want" attitude
towards military spending is a luxury we
can no longer afford.
Beyond a Certain Point
The advance of nuclear weaponry has
introduced a new factor into strategic
calculus: beyond a certain point
additional military appropriations and
equipment may not be translatable into
increased national security or useful
political power. In other words, since
both the Soviet Union and the United
States have sufficient nuclear power to
start a nuclear attack and then to
destroy the attackers' society with a
second strike, additional dollars spent
on weapons do not necessarily enhance
our strength or security.
It is within this framework that I
would like to discuss the recent decision
to proceed with the deployment of an
anti-ballistic missile system.
Let me begin with a careful
the
Defense
examination
of
Department's reasons for requesting the
money for an ABM system. Though the
justifications for deploying ABM have
shifted with the political winds both
during this administration and the last,
Secretary of Defense Laird offered three
principal reasos for constructing the
Safeguard
system
during recent
Congressional hearings:
First, to defend against a
possible Chinese nuclear missile

attack;

—Second, to defend against a
"light" irrational or accidental

—Third, to protect a portion of
our offensive missile forces for a
second-strike capability against a
possible Soviet attempt to develop
potential to wipe out our

Don't Hold Water
At the same time, spokesmen for the
Defense Department indicated what the
ABM was not supposed to do.

limitation.
These arguments for the ABM simply

deployment of ABM installations
around our Minutemen sites in

rife

forseeable future to attempt to destroy
our second strike capability, that is,
our ability to absorb a nuclear attack
with enough of our missiles intact to
devastate China in response.
The proposed ABM system is simply
not designed to defend cities. The
contemplated ABM system consists of
two different types of missiles: the
Spartan missile which is designed to
intercept enemy missiles before they
re-enter earth's atmosphere and which
has a range of approximately 400 miles;
and the smaller Sprint missile, with a
range of 25-30 miles, which is supposed

penetrate the Spartan defense and
disarm them 100,000 feet above their
targets.
Devastate our Cities

only one of the nation's 25 largest cities

devastate our cities.

the U.S.S.R. would also be obliterated

such a Soviet attack might also be
"irrational" enough to be less than
"all-out" defies reason.
Why should any Soviet leader send
only a few missiles over when he knows
the U.S. will retaliate with its full
second-strike force? Even men as mad as
Hitler were never guilty of such
thoughtless accomodation to then
enemies. If the Soviets did attack, it
would certainly be with full force,

would render the proposed Safeguard
system useless.

that unintentionally "got away".

drastically less expensive ICBM's.
